awd_titl_txt: Electron Scattering and Neutrino Scattering from Light Nuclei
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent discovery of neutrino oscillations -- the change of neutrinos from one type to another -- has established that neutrinos have mass. This remarkable result has led to a lot of new questions about neutrinos and their interactions. The next-generation neutrino experiments seek to understand neutrinos in greater detail and a precise understanding of neutrino-nucleus reactions is necessary to plan and interpret these experiments. These reactions are very similar to electron-nucleus reactions that the PI has investigated successfully in the past. In this project, the PI will apply the approach developed for electron-nucleus scattering to the neutrino experiments. Beside their role in answering questions about the neutrinos themselves, neutrino-nucleus reactions reactions have the potential to reveal more information about light nuclei, in particular about the strangeness content of their building blocks, protons and neutrons. The PI will refine the calculation of electron and neutrino scattering in order to identify the most promising future experiments. This project will provide theoretical support to both neutrino and electron scattering experiments performed in the US. The PI will continue to do outreach in rural northwestern Ohio and involve interested undergraduate students in this research project.

Electron scattering from light nuclei provides insights on the structure of the nuclear ground state. The PI and her collaborators have developed a high precision description of electron-deuteron scattering. All elements of the electron scattering reaction mechanism are necessary to describe neutrino scattering reactions on the same nuclei. There are many exciting neutrino scattering experiments that are running now or will run in the near future. In order to correctly interpret the neutrino data, a precise understanding of the nuclear physics involved is necessary. The current state of theory in the event generators used by experimental groups is fairly basic. The PI will adapt the knowledge of the electron scattering reaction mechanism to calculate the neutrino scattering. She will investigate neutral current neutrino scattering from the deuteron. The differential cross section depends on the strangeness content of the nucleons. Using a deuteron target allows one to access the information contained in the neutron. The PI will investigate the sensitivity to the three relevant parameters describing the strangeness content of the nucleon, and will discuss ways to put a theoretical error bar on these values.

por.por_cntn:
Electron scattering allows us to explore the detailed structure of nuclei. At high electron energies, we can access information on the small distance structures inside a nucleus. Electron scattering is particularly well suited for the study of nuclei as they interact through the electromagnetic interaction, and not through the strong interaction that binds the constituents of the nucleus. An important part of the contemporary study of electron scattering is to provide model calculations for a precise description of the initial state, electromagnetic interactions, and final state of the reactions. It is equally important to develop and deploy a formalism that characterizes the types of nuclear responses that may be accessed with electron scattering in various experimental situations. This formalism needs to be applicable to fixed target experiments as well as collider experiments. This is especially relevant in view of the preparation for the advent of the Electron-Ion Collider at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

My collaborators and I have reviewed the status of the formalism for electron scattering from spin 1/2 targets, with polarization, and detection of a particle in coincidence with the scattered electron in the final state. The beginnings of this formalism were developed a long time ago, when only inclusive electron scattering, without detecting any other particle in coincidence, could be performed. Historically, with access to better - and harder to perform - experiments, the formalism was expanded. We have reviewed the entire, generalized tensor structure of the nuclear responses. As a major outcome of this project, we have provided an invariant form of these responses, as well as relationships between our invariant responses and frame-dependent responses. This is of great practical relevance, as theoretical calculations typically are easiest to perform, or can only be performed, in the rest frame. In order to study electron scattering in different frames, e.g. in a collider experiment, the theory calculations have to be Lorentz-boosted. This is a procedure that is at best very cumbersome, and often practically impossible. Our results provide an easy way to apply theoretical calculations from any frame to other, arbitrary frames.

 

Another exciting area is the study of neutrinos. In the last decade, great progress has been, and we finally have learned that neutrinos are not massless. Currently, there is a lot of experimental effort in the field to go beyond the initial discovery of neutrino oscillations, which showed that neutrinos must have mass, to study neutrino properties in more detail. Neutrino experiments are difficult as neutrinos have tiny interaction cross sections, and neutrino beam energies are often impossible to determine precisely. Neutrino nucleus scattering is relevant to the construction of new detectors for the next generation of neutrino experiments, as well as in its own right, as neutrino scattering allows us to study the strangeness content of nucleons in the nucleus.

We applied our expertise in electron scattering from light nuclei to the calculation of cross sections of neutrino scattering on the deuteron. The initial state and the final state interactions for electron-deuteron scattering and neutrino-deuteron scattering are identical, and only the interaction operators an form factors had to be adjusted. Our results show in which areas one finds sensitivity to the strangeness content of the nucleon.
